captions.text:
- So my dad told me when
I was little that if I
continuously played with my belly button,

it would come untied,
causing my butt to fall off,
because that's how my butt was attached.
(guitar music)

- When I used to go to
church when I was little,

and they talked about the
Virgin Mary, I asked my parents
what a virgin was, and they told me it was
someone who never ate meat.

So as a six year old, I
went around telling everyone

I could never be a virgin
because I liked meat too much.

- When I was eight or nine,
my father enjoyed telling me

that at age 11, the webs
between my fingers and my toes
needed to be cut, snipped off.

- When I was 10 years old,
my dad told me that my pet
guinea pig was given away to a nun.
That a nun knocked on our door and said

that the orphanage needed
pets for the kids to play with
so he gave her mine.
I was like, "Dad, you're Jewish.
"Why do you care what a nun says?"

- My parents told me the
lie that since my vehicle
was so old, that the speedometer was off,
and it was fast five miles an hour.
I believed that lie for about five years,

and I always drove five
miles under the speed limit
until I found out that was not true.

- When I was five, and
I would want ice cream,

my dad would say, "Oh no,
you can't have any ice cream,

"because you know, the man
who makes the ice cream,
"he died."
- When you lose teeth, if you throw them

on top of the roof, a rat
will come and take them away.
- Light bulbs, if they break, they release
the world's most toxic gas.

So I didn't change light
bulbs until I was an adult.
A week ago.

- The lie they told me
was that if you don't eat
your vegetables, you'll grow worms.

So of course, I grew up and
told my children the same thing.
I told them if they didn't eat vegetables
that worms would come out of their butt.

- When I was four years
old, my mother told me
that if I sat too close to the TV,

they'd have to scoop my
eyeballs out with teaspoons.

And I passed that one on to
my three year old daughter.

title: The Weirdest Lies Parents Tell Their Kids

comments.text:
My dad told my brother for YEARS that if he had his way, my brother's name 
would have been Scrotum (this was when my brother was too young to know 
what that word means). After years of hearing this, my brother casually 
asked my mother why she got to pick his name, and why wasn't he named 
Scrotum, like dad wanted. My mother's reaction was a bizarre mix of anger 
and laughing so hard she could barely explain to him what that word mean, 
and tell him that they were never going to name him that. He also told us 
that brussels sprouts were giant's boogers, and I wouldn't try one until my 
teens.﻿
